posts.text: Renewing the adhesive on a phone screen protector:Howdy folks, I was researching the best way to reapply or renew the adhesive on a phone's screen protector. And by "research", I mean popping in and seeing who has had success with what? I was thinking about a Loctite LOCA glue, but wasn't sure.

posts.quote: o reapply or renew the adhesive on a phone's screen protector
posts.text: Even application of the desired thickness (or rather thinness) plus ensuring there's no foreign debris is extremely difficult with hand tools and the level of cleanliness possible at most homes and workplaces.

posts.author: Andrewcw
posts.text: One and done. There is no renewal. Once you stick it to the surface taking it off to reposition it basically ruins the adhesive. Unless you somehow figure out the cost effective way to clean the I assume glass with acetone and have the machinery to spray at micron sized particles with the correct adhesive.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: I mean... is this one of those crazy $50 screen protectors that is basically the same as the $3 ones? Cause I've been using the $3 for years with great results. I would say a new screen protector is cheaper than the glue you might need.

posts.author: davidtheweb
posts.quote: I mean... is this one of those crazy $50 screen protectors that is basically the same as the $3 ones? Cause I've been using the $3 for years with great results. I would say a new screen protector is cheaper than the glue you might need.
posts.text: I suppose that's what will need to happen, as long as they stay in production.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: I'd just buy 10 of them now then if you are worried about that. If it is a popular model, it will probably have screen protectors available for the life of the phone (5 to 7 years at most).

posts.author: hestermofet
posts.text: Chromebooks - Advantage to ARM or Intel?:I haven't followed Chrome OS in a while. A couple years ago, there was a slight advantage to having an ARM Chromebook because Android software support was superior compared to Intel. Is this still the case? Any other gotchas with CPU ISA? Weirdly, Celeron Chromebooks are a bit cheaper than ARM Chromebooks.

posts.author: Defenestrar
posts.text: It gets down to what you want to do with the unit. Traditionally you could get heavier lift with an Intel CPU, but people rarely buy Chromebooks for heavy lifting.

posts.author: Andrewcw
posts.text: It has to do with OEM buying power buy 10,000 POS CPU's and we'll lower the cost of the higher CPU's because of volume discounts.

posts.author: Neill78
posts.text: I think it's better to just look at some reviews for models that interest you and fit your price range. When I was shopping I found that there are good and bad ARM chips, good and bad implementations of both ARM and Celeron chips, and great chips in some terrible hardware. Device reviews will generally give you overall comparative data to help you choose between devices. The CPU is basically the last thing to worry about in a Chromebook unless you have a really specific use case that I can't really imagine.

posts.author: GeneralFailureDriveA
posts.quote: I haven't followed Chrome OS in a while. A couple years ago, there was a slight advantage to having an ARM Chromebook because Android software support was superior compared to Intel. Is this still the case? Any other gotchas with CPU ISA? Weirdly, Celeron Chromebooks are a bit cheaper than ARM Chromebooks.
posts.text: You may wish to look into the state of the media DRM ecosystems if you intend to use a Chromebook as a media playback device. On x86, DRM works, on ARM, it worked on 32-bit, but I am not certain as to the state of 64-bit ARM DRM support. I simply do not care enough to keep up with it, but it is a possible issue.

posts.author: hestermofet
posts.text: This was more an academic question than something that will inform a purchasing decision. I had a Samsung Chromebook before that used ARM, and bought a used Acer last year from a thrift store that uses a Celeron. Just was curious if there is any difference between the two in terms of software support, as there used to be.

posts.author: .劉煒
posts.text: Depends on workload.

posts.author: Neill78
posts.text: I haven't tried a Celeron powered Chromebook yet. The battery life always seems to be worse than ARM.

posts.author: mrsilver
posts.text: Best way to move a shared iPad to a child:Hi all,

posts.author: Andrewcw
posts.text: iDevices are single account. So unless your daughter is under their own account they might lose everything.

posts.author: ant1pathy
posts.text: I would personally be a lot more comfortable doing a full device wipe and set her up with her own child iCloud account attached to the family plan. You'll likely lose the app/game data, but it's a "rip the bandaid off at once" kind of thing and going forward for the next years (as she gets a new iPad and phone at some point) will be in better shape.

posts.author: Sogarth
posts.text: Most game data won't be tied to your iCloud data, so your plan would work for most apps (a handful of games will keep game data in iCloud and not device backups, so you might need to log into restore that game data). Any DLC (e.g. unlocking "full" games or expansions) is unlikely to be supported for family sharing, although games bought straight from the App Store should be fine. But, as you imagine, it'll be kind of a PITA to go through every app - doing mass deletions from Storage would probably be the easiest way to do it.

posts.author: Tinlad
posts.quote: I would personally be a lot more comfortable doing a full device wipe and set her up with her own child iCloud account attached to the family plan. You'll likely lose the app/game data, but it's a "rip the bandaid off at once" kind of thing and going forward for the next years (as she gets a new iPad and phone at some point) will be in better shape.
posts.text: I would agree with this.

posts.author: mrsilver
posts.text: In case anyone wonders, I bit the bullet, factory reset the iPad and started from scratch. It made sense to do it properly now, rather than half-ass it and have to live with various annoyances.

posts.author: g00ey
posts.text: Dell Precision M6000 series PremierColor upgrade:I've been interested for a while in upgrading a Dell M6800 to an SLB3 display panel which supports 10-bit color. Although there are Dell mobile workstations that support 10-bit color, I know that you cannot just fit an ordinary one with an 3/4 LCD as they require different connectors (to accomodate the higher bit depth).

Ugh, if it's different connectors on the LCD panel and the motherboard you have doesn't have those connectors (or if there's some firmware upgrade/lockout) you might be SOL. I have no idea on the process either so would be curious what you can find. OTOH if it's the same connectors you might have a good shot at it working.

posts.author: Andrewcw
posts.text: Judging how partspeople is selling parts for your M6800 sounds like it's a different motherboard.

posts.author: abj
posts.text: Yeah there are two seperate boards, one uses LVDS and the other uses eDP. There is no good way to convert between them that I am aware of.

posts.author: g00ey
posts.text: I've seen on the motherboards that they use LVDS or eDP depending on model. All LVDS ports are 40-pin on the Dell. On laptops such as the HP zBook, there is an eDP -> LVDS converter board (based on the RealTek RTD2136R chip). On HP laptops it is called DreamColor. Perhaps those Dell laptops that use PremierColor uses the eDP interface together with that board.

posts.author: Andrewcw
posts.quote: I find it kind of strange but it is hard to tell whether I would get Premier/DreamColor when going to the Dell (or HP) website to get a new laptop. Do video editors and photographers no longer use laptops? Also now that we have HDR features coming up, there should be a higher demand for displays with 10-bit color or more (per channel).
posts.text: Yes but i'd take a stab most of them use Apple now with that M1 running circles around what else was available specifically when it comes to AV processing. Or when they're using the laptop they're not doing the final render of anything so color grading it's as important.

posts.author: bkaral

posts.text: The light areas on one I looked at for him were about 1/4 inch to 1/2 inch in size.

posts.author: Xelas
posts.text: The light/dark spots could also be moire effect with the camera's sensor and screen pixels. It can be very pronounced in some cases, and you have to move around or tilt the camera slightly to make them go away (then crop and/or rotate the image afterwards).

posts.author: Paladin

Heck, I might go for a large tablet with a physical bluetooth keyboard if typing is important. If it's just content consumption as most people do, a tablet would be totally fine.

posts.author: asbath

She has a desktop at home that she uses to process all of her photos, but occasionally needs to be able to touch up some images on the go. SD card slot would be convenient, but unnecessary since she has a USB SD card reader.

Around 500-600 for the laptop, around 100 for the replacement battery.

posts.text: USB-C multi laptop charger <- does this product exist?:Hello,

You need USB-PD (USB Power Delivery) with appropriate power output to each port for each laptop. Laptops usually* need between 45W and 250W to charge, in the case of typical consumer grade laptops that rely on the CPU’s built-in GPU it’s usually between 45W and 65W.

posts.author: steelghost
posts.text: The easy, inexpensive way to do this is to buy x2 multi-outlet devices (in the UK I'd call it a plug strip) that will let you plug all the adaptors in at once. No, it's not pretty, but with some velcro straps etc it could be made tolerable. And it has the benefit of being something you can actually buy.

posts.author: R4360
posts.text: There isn't going to be a single solution that can supply enough wattage to charge 10 machines using Power Delivery. 2-3 will be the max there, I think.

posts.author: iljitsch
posts.text: Yeah ten laptops through one adapter is asking a bit much.

posts.author: Andrewcw
posts.text: Because you'd need every expensive chargers to handle the load. They'd be expensive because the cost would go up exponentially up and the profit because of unsold units because they cost more would go down. Probably why you won't find chargers attempt to break 150Watts. The market would be too niche.

posts.author: DarkSyd
posts.text: What about something like a classroom charging station or cabinet?

posts.text: Health focused smartwatches work great without a phone. I have a Garmin Fenix 3 which will work perfectly fine with 100% functionality if the only thing you pair it to is a PC. You'll only miss out on notification of stuff like emails and IM messages... but since IM messages come through on your smartwatch instead of your PC, that's kind of a given. My wife has a Fitbit Versa 3 which also works well with a PC only, but it does work best with a smartphone. Both Garmin and Fitbit started out with products that were meant to pair first and foremost with a PC, before Apple launched the first product that worked exclusively with a smartphone. Both Garmin and Fitbit still provide a lot of functionality if you pair exclusively with a PC, but Fitbit's smartwatches work

posts.text: Verizon? Why would they need access to your phone to collect and sell data? If you use them for mobile service they can simply collect everything they want as it passes through their own equipment. Anything that is encrypted on your phone is safe from direct access from them whether they try to collect data on the phone itself or on the 'air' as it passes through their systems. They simply use voluntarily submitted usage data and collected metadata from connection points and location data from your usage. No need to fiddle in your phone or try to intercept anything between your watch and phone.

posts.text: How to clean a dirty/dusty/sticky laptop?:I have an old dell xps laptop that I been using for years. The exterior part you do not see much issues. But when you lift up the lid on the laptop, not only is there a ton of dust throughout the keyboard, the part right between the bottom of the laptop screen right below the Dell logo... and the top part of the laptop keyboard, is very sticky. I notice this a long time ago and had no idea how that even happened. Its like gooey and sticky etc. Now the thing is where I stay at, its very humid so the dust on my laptop keyboard makes sense. But I have no idea how my laptop got so sticky. A while back I remember I had a tough time opening my laptop as in lifting the lid of it to use it because of the stickyness. I remember then using one of those lens wipes you use for laptop screens and glasses etc to get the stickyness out. But its still sticky. I can take a picture of it for you all to take a look but my whole keyboard has a ton of dust all over it. I also have an external keyboard that is very dirty as well. Can take picture of that as well. But I like the external keyboard so I never bought another one because this keyboard is comforatable.

Try that and report back.

posts.text: Samsung Watch 4 - clearing notifcations?:I just got a Samsung Watch 4 (not Classic), with LTE capabilities but I'm currently just tethering it via bluetooth to a Samsung Note 8. I primarily got it to more easily/quickly deal with notifications, but I'm having trouble understanding how to deal with them effectively. This is my first "Smart" watch, so I have no preconceived notions on how WearOS watches work - all my friends have Apple devices.

posts.author: Xelas
posts.text: This seems to be a common complaint. IMHO, notifications on Samsung watches are badly broken. When they released the Watch4 that's WearOS-based and not Tizen-based, they ported over their "broken" notification system instead of what I think is the much more logical stock WearOS notification panel.

posts.author: Velvet G
posts.text: Don't know if it's the same as with Tizen (I use an Active 2) but when you open the notification, there are three dots to the right. Tap it and you can delete, clear, open on phone.

posts.author: Nevarre
posts.text: Yeah it's a messed up situation. Googled granted them a year's exclusivity for the new Wear OS to woo them back from running Tizen, but they skinned it like Tizen and include Bixby instead of Google Assistant. Meanwhile, nobody else can use the improved Wear OS (skinned like Wear OS) until 2022.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: That's kinda weird, if they copied the design from the older Samsung watches, the notifications are pretty decent. I have a Galaxy Watch S3 Frontier that uses the Tizen software and the notifications are great. Rotate/swipe to the left and you get the notifications. You can swipe them up to dismiss them, tap them to read more or show the full item on your phone. Once you go all the way to the left there is an icon of a garbage can that will clear all notifications. No problems.

posts.author: Xelas
posts.quote: Don't know if it's the same as with Tizen (I use an Active 2) but when you open the notification, there are three dots to the right. Tap it and you can delete, clear, open on phone.
posts.text: No, the new WearOS based watches don't have that. You either have to review all notifications from a single app then dismiss them all at once by simply swiping up on the latest one, or you have to scroll ALL the way down, hit the "More" button, then scroll down again, then hit "Clear" to clear just that one notification.

posts.author: Xelas
posts.quote: ... Rotate/swipe to the left and you get the notifications.
posts.text: That's still true, I think. As you swipe left, you see "batches" of notifications grouped by app. So for example, all Outlook notifications, then swipe left for all Messages, etc. If there is more than one notification from that app, there is a number on the bottom. If you swipe up at this point, you dismiss ALL notifications from that app.

posts.author: asbath
posts.text: Repair/replace Lightning port on iPhone 6?:So I've got my hands on a damaged iPhone 6, which I want to give to a family who could really use a phone. Problem is that the lightning port is finicky - seems like the previous owners dropped the phone while plugged in, and the cable bent the port's pins so it's incredibly temperamental.

posts.author: Entegy
posts.text: Apple Store or Apple Authorized Service Provider is your best bet here.

posts.author: toasterwaffle86
posts.text: I tried this on a 6s and wouldn’t advise it.

Have you made sure it's cleaned out? Get a toothpick or piece of 18AWG solid or something in there and clean out any lint that's accumulated at the base. A lot of the time, a flakey Lightning port is just one so packed full of lint that the cable can't seat. Don't be afraid to be a bit aggressive - it can be packed in quite tightly. You should see shiny metal at the far end.

posts.author: ant1pathy
posts.quote: Have you made sure it's cleaned out?  Get a toothpick or piece of 18AWG solid or something in there and clean out any lint that's accumulated at the base.  A lot of the time, a flakey Lightning port is just one so packed full of lint that the cable can't seat.  Don't be afraid to be a bit aggressive - it can be packed in quite tightly.  You should see shiny metal at the far end.
posts.text: Seconded, although I would urge wood or plastic only (toothpicks are great!). Metal can scratch and score the pins, although if the next step is replacement I guess there's no downside

posts.author: asbath
posts.text: Yup, I went (gentle) ham with a toothpick, and made sure the port is as clean as can be. However, I could see that the port was "cracked" open, and it looks like a lightning cable expanded the port vertically (if you have the phone lying face up). The port basically appears physically damaged. The only way to charge the phone is to put a couple layers of painter's tape on the top of the lightning cable plug to push the plug downward and make contact with the pins inside the port.

posts.author: AndrewZ
posts.text: I had the same problem with a different model. Took it in to get cleaned and problem solved!

posts.author: slaimus
posts.text: Limit Mobile Data Usage With VoLTE:I recently switched from an AT&T MVNO to a Verizon MVNO, and need suggestions on how to limit data usage.
Is there no setting to only turn off cellular data on whatever version of iOS is on your iPhone 6S?

posts.author: hestermofet
posts.quote: However, with Verizon turning off 3G and forcing VoLTE, this is no longer an option. Turning off LTE will also turn off voice and text as well since they use VoLTE.
posts.text: That's pretty dumb. I know that 3G on CDMA (CDMA20000, EVDO) wouldn't let you use voice and data at the same time because they were different networks and there would be contention over the modem/antenna, but ever since GSM networks hit 3G, voice has been transmitted over the same packet-switched network as data. Even though they used the exact same network software and hardware stack, turning off the "data" setting on your phone didn't turn off voice, it was just a software setting that blocked applications other than the Dialer from using data. Your carrier should be smart enough to not bill you for voice packets, and your phone OS should be smart enough not to allow application-layer packets over the network while still allowing packets from the Dialer app. It's more like an outbout firewall rule* than a hardware setting change.

posts.author: cogwheel
posts.text: The real WTF here is that VoLTE is being billed as data, and counting against your cap, when it's less impactful than non-VoLTE calling in terms of network capacity.

posts.author: toasterwaffle86
posts.quote: The real WTF here is that VoLTE is being billed as data, and counting against your cap, when it's less impactful than non-VoLTE calling in terms of network capacity.
posts.text: The way I'm reading it, they didn't say that. They're just shutting off LTE to ensure apps can't use data without explicit permission.

posts.author: hestermofet
posts.quote: They're just shutting off LTE to ensure apps can't use data without explicit permission.
posts.text: No it won't. You want to shut off data for that. Turning off LTE in a foreign country will just have iCloud rack you up a huge bill on 3G.

posts.author: toasterwaffle86
posts.text: Unless they're using LTE as a euphemism for data?

posts.author: hestermofet
posts.quote: Unless they're using LTE as a euphemism for data?
posts.text: If that's the case, turn off data and don't worry about it. Voice calls will still work.

data.title: USB C fail: How to plug in a wired earphone/mic into usb c plug that works
data.author: hinduclient
data.text: USB C fail: How to plug in a wired earphone/mic into usb c plug that works:USB C almost does it all - it charges, provides Ethernet connection, HDMI connection, USB connections, and decent audio out for audio devices. But what about wired headphones? I paid $10 for a USB-C to 3.5mm dongle. Music from the phone sounds great - but audio from a phone call doesn't pass through. The Mic seems to work but I don't hear audio from the phone.

posts.author: paulyron
posts.text: Preserve Laptop Battery Life Span When Plugged In Always?:Hey all. I mentioned I got a new laptop battery for my dell xps 15 9550 which is an old machine for many years. Now with this laptop and previous laptops I had, I use it mainly as a desktop... connected to an ac charger and connected to external monitors. Pretty much im plugged in almost always.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: The Asus laptop I bought my wife last spring has an Asus power management tool (part of the whole system management software package) that has an option to preserve battery lifetime by never charging past 80% or 85% I think. Leave it plugged in all the time and it will never go past 85% or so. If you don't have a software option for that, just keep an eye on it and try to do the same. That or just look into buying a replacement battery for it. Wait for prices to go down as they become common and buy one before the price goes back up as they become harder to find. I got one for my Lenovo a while ago, I don't really need it yet, my battery still charges fine, just not as much as when new. The replacement was $25. I'll install it some day.

posts.author: steelghost
posts.text: I have a Lenovo T450 laptop that is my work-issue daily driver, just over 4 years old now. It spends almost all its time on a desk, closed, plugged into power and connected to a screen, keyboard / mouse and ethernet, with it's little HSF being beaten to death by the somewhat twitchy software stack my employer uses (point being, it's running hard which makes it warm, which isn't ideal for the battery).

posts.author: paulyron
posts.text: Okay so you seem to say better to make it a setting to let it charge up to a certain percentage thing ... so that is better then?

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: My Lenovo is probably around 6 months to a year older than yours, assuming you have the core i7 6600u. Mine is a core i7 5500u, still silly fast for most things I ever do on it. Mine is a 35 Wh battery, not very big. The U31-70 I have is a 13 inch basically and quite slim so not much room for battery. Still lasts around 4 hours of moderate use though, when it was new I could go 6-8 at best and this thing has a GeForce 920M in it using some power sometimes too. I checked the price I paid, it was actually more like $35 shipped so not quite as cheap as I thought, there are still some offers under $30 for it but the sellers are not too reliable looking.

posts.author: asbath
posts.text: Heat, age, and constant complete discharge/recharge are probably the worst offenders for batteries and long-term lifespan. If you keep it plugged in and relatively cool (i.e. the laptop isn't burning hot all the time), it shouldn't be wearing down your battery that much. You should expect the battery to lose anywhere more than 5% overall capacity a year... how much it actually deteriorates depends on how much you really use that battery.

posts.author: paulyron
posts.text: My laptop was bought late 2016. The processor is an i5-6300hq.. its a quad core laptop. Your laptop is an i7 but its a U processor... which means its not a powerful laptop but one with long battery. I remember years ago it was laptop with HQ, its quad core and very fast/powerful but give up battery... the U series were meant to be not powerful laptops but long battery. Im surprised the wh battery on your laptop is so small since its a U series laptop.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: The one I bought is a Lenovo battery, at least it certainly appears genuine. Whether the cells in it are of high quality or not is another question but for the price I'm not that worried if they turn out to be less than perfect when it comes to longevity. It's a ~5 year old laptop at this point so if I get another year or two out of it I will be very happy and move on to whatever looks good at that point.

posts.author: koala
posts.text: To give some more background.

posts.author: hestermofet
posts.text: Well, if you stick with AMD CPUs, you can get a lot more life out of the motherboard. I'm guessing you needed to upgrade motherboards last time because you had an Intel CPU, and the socket on those change almost every single generation. An AMD motherboard bought back in 2018 will still work with the CPUs that were JUST announced a couple days ago and aren't even available for sale yet. Those CPUs will still be competitive for another 2 years, so that's about 4 years of top of the line performance from a single motherboard. An X550 or X570 chipset motherboard bought today will probably last another 3-4 years.

posts.author: quanticle
posts.text: What's the best LTE capable laptop, these days?:Just like the thread subject says, what's the best LTE capable laptop, these days? I'm asking because I'm on Google Project Fi now, and one of the advantages of it is that you can order up to 4 additional SIM cards (for a total of 5), that tie into your existing Project Fi data plan. So, given that, I'm thinking, "Why am I tethering my laptop to my phone like a chump and burning my phone's battery, when I can just have a laptop that can hop onto an LTE connection on its own?"

posts.author: LordAthens
posts.text: With the advent of being able to tether on nearly every phone produced or mobile hotspots, WWAN laptops have pretty much had their day. Not to say they don't exist, but seriously, don't base buying a laptop on that. Especially when your only concern is phone battery life. Charge your phone through your laptop if it's that big of a deal. Buy a 20kmah battery pack. There is no good reason to have a WWAN adapter in a laptop at this point*, especially with hardware changes on the cellular side, like T-Mobile B12 support.

posts.author: Hat Monster
posts.text: Don't base your laptop purchasing decision on a $20 USB dongle.

posts.author: quanticle
posts.quote: Don't base your laptop purchasing decision on a $20 USB dongle
posts.text: Fair enough, but in that case, what's a decent USB LTE modem? I've been looking for some, all the unlocked ones seem kinda shady, with none getting more than three-and-a-half stars on Amazon. There are decent hotspots and USB dongles out there, it seems, but they're all carrier (usually Verizon) exclusive.

posts.author: Hat Monster
posts.text: They all seem fairly generic among the ones I've come across, mostly Huawei and ZTE units. They're commoditised very strongly.

posts.author: Entegy
posts.text: However, there are laptops in HP's Elite range that have SIM slots. And Windows has built-in cellular connection stuff now, so no silly software to try and connect.

posts.author: Baenwort
posts.text: The zBook line also has internal sim card support.

posts.author: sryan2k1
posts.text: I'd just get a Wifi Hotspot "Jetpack" device and use that instead of a USB modem. Then any device can attach to it and most of them can be powered on while charging.

posts.author: Visigoth
posts.text: YA laptop recommendation thread, with a twist:I currently have a eMachines M6805 system which I really quite like. It has a good amount of power (especially after a memory and HD upgrade) and has been able to handle everything I've thrown at it. The problem is that like other eMachines laptops the hinges have cracked. I tried, repeatedly, to get it replaced, but never got much response from eMachines and now that my warranty is expired and that they don't exist I doubt I'll ever get it replaced by them. Honestly, the system is fine and have not had any problems with it so far, but I'm worried that at some point I'll go to open/close the screen and the hinges will break. One possibly good thing is that I bought this at Best Buy and purchased the 3-year support plan. While I'm not sure how they will handle this I'm thinking of taking it in and seeing what they will do to either replace it or maybe they would have better luck getting it fixed by eMachines/Gateway. So here are my questions.If they opt to replace it would they give me the original purchase price ($1,499) towards a new machine? If so what would you all suggest as a replacement laptop that would stay within the original purchase price while getting the most bang for the buck?

posts.author: R4360
posts.text: Odds of him getting money instead of store credit are somewhere between slim and none. He'll be stuck with either picking something out of store stock with it, or using the store credit for other things more than likely. posts.author: Alaskadiver
posts.text: Buying cellphones online vs locally. Comments?:Hi guys. The two year contracts on my wife and my verizon phones have expired so we are free too look elsewhere. I was contemplating going with Cingular and getting the Nokia 6102 or Motorola V551 or RAZr. At this point I'm leaning to the Nokia for battery life and signal strength. I'm also looking at the Cingular Nation 700 minute family plan. These are the different prices I've found:Letstalk.complan w/2 year contract: 60.00/moNokia 6102: free (instant rebate)v550: free (instant rebate)RAZr: free (instant rebate)Wirefly.complan w/2 year contract: 69.99/moNokia 6102: free w/180 day rebatev550: free w/180 day rebateRAZr: free w/180 day rebateverizon.complan w/2 year contract: 69.99/moNokia 6102: $89v550: $99RAZr: $199Verizon local storeplan w/2 year contract: 69.99/moNokia 6102: $89v550: $99RAZr: $199Am I missing something here? I read as much of the fine print as possible and it appears that the LetsTalk.com $60/mo contract for the Family Talk Nation 700 plan is identical in every way to the $69.99 Family Talk Nation 700 plan offered by Cingular and Wirefly. In addition, I get the instant rebate from letstalk.com rather than having to wait 180 days with wirefly and no rebate at all from Cingular online or B&M stores.I also assume that all of the taxes and fees that are percentage-based will be lower on a $60 plan rather than a $69.99 plan so I may save slightly more than $10/mo.Is there something I'm missing here? Some catch or fine print that I'm unaware of? If not, what reason is there for paying an extra $200 for the phones and an extra $10/mo to get the phone locally?

posts.author: dyrstr8s
posts.text: Here's something I just stumbled into. I was looking to get a phone and plan again, haven't had any for a while. My wife has Cingular so I tended towards that and I love the V3 Razr in black.Went to the Cingular web site and couldn't find anything I would consider a deal. There's a space on their site to enter your e-mail address and they'll e-mail you back a link to their Premier site with specials just for your company, base on your e-mail address.I put in my work address and promptly got an e-mail that working for my company entitled me to: a free Razr phone, free shipping, free $20 in accessories, and a 450 anytime/unlimited eve/wkend plan for $39.99/mo and a $36 activation fee. Sounded good but I wanted to run it by my wife that evening, I was at work.Later that night at home, the wife said sure, go for it. But from home I couldn't access my work e-mail to get the link. So I gave the website my home email, a standard isp address, out of desperation. The reply I got said that as a State of Texas employee I qualified for: a free Razr, free shipping, $25 in accessories, and the same plan for $33.99/mo and no activation fee!Despite the fact that I live in Iowa and do NOT work for the state of Texas, got my phone today and I love it!Sorry for the long story, but my point is, put in your e-mail address at the Cingular site and see what they offer you.

posts.text: The dealer can't give you a special plan. posts.author: brodie
posts.text: As far as the plans go, I'll quote my earlier reply in the Cingular thread:quote:They were somewhat misleading.... intentionally or not... the FT plan is $60/month plus $10/month for each additional line. Since you must have at least two lines to have a family talk plan, $70/month is essentially the price. That is, you'll never get the $60/month price, because you need at least two lines. It's been this way since June, when the plans changed over. You can't assign a single phone to a family talk plan... you can't now, and you couldn't a few weeks ago. The system won't let the CSR change it to that. You need to have two lines. The OLD plans (pre-June) let you do that, but they fixed that.

posts.author: Alaskadiver
posts.text: Well, I've learned a heck of a lot in the past week of cell phone research. Every time I look for something new (laptop, camera, phone, car) I plunge head first into the datastream and absorb as much as possible then after making a decision I don't look back and never read anything more until the next go-round. Since my wife's 2.5 year old audiovox cdm9500 from verizon is about dead (she has to pull the battery out to reboot to get it to work half the time now) she is bugging me to get something new.After popping by the Cingular and T-Mobile corporate stores I discovered that 5 minutes on their corporate web sites and howardforums gave me more knowledge than the average store clerk in those stores [good God though, some of those howardforums guys scare me. They're just phones not objects of love and obsession] The T-mobile corporate store experience was especially horrifying. Since I frequently travel to Alaska on business I asked whether there were roaming charges for Alaska. He futzed with his computer for a while until finally I walked around the counter to find him searching for Alaska through some international roaming page. No, Alaska is not between Afganistan and Algeria. What do they teach in schools these days? Anyway, he finally found Alaska on the map after I gave him an Anchorage address to type in and we discovered that all the cities were covered with green checked zones on the map indicating USA roaming coverage. So he tells me that yes I can get roaming service but he can't tell me the charge because that is determined by the roaming partner. Of course once home I discovered that all roaming within the US is free with T-mobile just like with Cingular. Idiot. So tell me again WHY I'm supposed to pay a hefty price premium to get this phone locally vs online for free? I wasted 1/2 hour in the store only to get information that was 100% wrong.I can maybe forgive ignorance at Best Buy where the clerks have to juggle 3 or 4 cell carriers plus work other departments. But to have a job in a corporate T-Mobile store and be utterly clueless about basic plan features and be unable to find the answers? Don't even get me started on their knowledge of their phone lineup. They guy didn't even know that the Nokia on display was a plastic model and not the real thing.Anyway, despite the horrifying experience at the T-mobile store (Cingular wasn't much better) I decided to give T-Mobile a try. We've been happy with Verizon but even after having been Verizon customers for 3 years and never getting a new phone they want us to renew for 2 years just to get $100 off a new phone. I can get a new T-mobile 700 minute family plan for $10/mo cheaper than Verizon or Cingular and two new Nokia 6101 phones for free with only a 1-year contract. And T-mobile will unlock the phones after 3 months so we can use them in Chile. Even if we end up hating T-mobile I can switch to a new carrier in a year or less and we'll still have the unlocked Nokia phones for travel to Chile. Heck, I would still come out even switching back to Verizon or Cingular in 9 months if we hate T-Mobile and just running both contracts concurrently for three months. The price savings is that much over renewing with Verizon now ($120 savings on the rate plan plus $100 savings on the phones = $220 which is 3 months of T-mobile service with all the fees included).Now we'll see how the experience goes ordering phones online with letstalk.com or wirefly.com as amazon won't let me do it with my zip code.

posts.author: Aroc
posts.text: cingular will unlock phones after 3-6 months with an account in good standing. Back in July I called Cingular (dial 611) and inquired about "SIM Subsidy Unlock" for GSM/GPRS Cingular Treo 650, in order to use pre-paid internation GSM SIM cards to avoid Cingular International roaming rates. The unlock code is tied to each phones unique IMEI number and the Carrier code (Cingular Orange). From the phone,Press Green Dial key.Press *#*#dial the 8-digit code they give you.Press the center D pad buttonPress the Green Dial key. You should receive confirmation of the unlock. Then try some pre-paid GSM SIM. It should work. It did in our case. Granted their first six answers will be "NO." But unless you are the type of person that can't or won't haggle the price on anything, I can see why you might not be able to get an unlock code. But most anyone else should be able to do it. Aaron

data.title: Buying cellphones online vs locally. Comments?
data.author: Alaskadiver
data.text: Buying cellphones online vs locally. Comments?:Hi guys. The two year contracts on my wife and my verizon phones have expired so we are free too look elsewhere. I was contemplating going with Cingular and getting the Nokia 6102 or Motorola V551 or RAZr. At this point I'm leaning to the Nokia for battery life and signal strength. I'm also looking at the Cingular Nation 700 minute family plan. These are the different prices I've found:Letstalk.complan w/2 year contract: 60.00/moNokia 6102: free (instant rebate)v550: free (instant rebate)RAZr: free (instant rebate)Wirefly.complan w/2 year contract: 69.99/moNokia 6102: free w/180 day rebatev550: free w/180 day rebateRAZr: free w/180 day rebateverizon.complan w/2 year contract: 69.99/moNokia 6102: $89v550: $99RAZr: $199Verizon local storeplan w/2 year contract: 69.99/moNokia 6102: $89v550: $99RAZr: $199Am I missing something here? I read as much of the fine print as possible and it appears that the LetsTalk.com $60/mo contract for the Family Talk Nation 700 plan is identical in every way to the $69.99 Family Talk Nation 700 plan offered by Cingular and Wirefly. In addition, I get the instant rebate from letstalk.com rather than having to wait 180 days with wirefly and no rebate at all from Cingular online or B&M stores.I also assume that all of the taxes and fees that are percentage-based will be lower on a $60 plan rather than a $69.99 plan so I may save slightly more than $10/mo.Is there something I'm missing here? Some catch or fine print that I'm unaware of? If not, what reason is there for paying an extra $200 for the phones and an extra $10/mo to get the phone locally?

posts.author: huelesnail
posts.text: I can confirm it is indeed the usb flex cable, same thing happened to me a week ago. The part costs between $15 and $20 and it's a fairly easy fix. You just need some plastic prying tools and a 00 phillips screwdriver. Removing the rear panel is a bit tricky the first time since it has some adhesive in the corners on top of the plastic clips, then remove all the screws (10 in total), disconnect all four connections from the usb flex and yank it out.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: Seems very normal. My S8 Active shows 2.2GB used by what it calls 'system and apps' after I tell it to clean up background apps. That is also out of 4GB on my phone.

posts.author: Hat Monster
posts.text: Yes, that's fine, if even a bit low. Android doesn't aggressively cache files as much as upstream Linux does, so it doesn't use as much RAM as it otherwise could, meaning more is wasted.

posts.author: crazy_vag
posts.text: If that amount is indeed normal, what's a good way to tell why my apps quit. For example, I'll be streaming music in the background, get a text and try to attach a photo, but SoundCloud will be forced out. I thought it was RAM contention, but now I'm not sure what to look for.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: Aggressive power saving config? Maybe your text app is nuts and takes 1GB of RAM or something?

posts.author: crazy_vag
posts.quote: Aggressive power saving config? Maybe your text app is nuts and takes 1GB of RAM or something?
posts.text: Right? I disappointed that Pixel doesn't give you any tools to understand that better. How about showing me a reason of why system killed the last 3 apps would be a start.

posts.author: Paladin
posts.text: I use Poweramp music player on my phone (Samsung S8 Active on Android 9 and LG v20 on Android 8) and both have options for the app to allow background activity. Go to the apps section, select the app and tap the battery section. It should show that option to let it run in the background. That's the only thing I know of to check. Never had a problem with a music player being killed off though. I also don't run any power management app or optimization. I get plenty of battery life as long as I don't have my screen on all the time.
